moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Nf3 g6 3. e3 Bg7 4. Bd3: Not much of a future for the bishop here, but the move is playable. I prefer 3. c4.
moves.4... O-O 5. O-O d6 6. b3: This might make sense if he intends to fianchetto the bishop. As it is, it just weakens the long dark diagonal.
moves.6... c5: Challenging the pawn that blocks that a1-h8 diagonal.
moves.7. c3: This reverse-Slav idea would be stronger if the b-pawn was still at b2. Now there's no good square for the QB.
moves.7... Nc6: Piling on the pressure at d4.
moves.8. Bd2: He should still fianchetto the QB. It's no use at d2.
moves.9. c4: ? This loses a pawn immediately and a rook eventually. Better was 9. h3, forcing black to retreat or exchange at f3. White's position would be highly playable after 9. Be2 as well.
moves.9... cxd4 10. exd4 Nxd4 11. Re1: Alternatives? Maybe 11. Be2, Nxe2+, 12. Qxe2, Nd7, 13. Bc3, Bxc3, 14. Nxc3, Ne5, 15. Qe4, Bxf3, 16. gxf3, Qd7. Black threatens ...Qh3 and ...Nxf3+, etc.
moves.11... Nxf3+ 12. gxf3 Be6: Black is a pawn up and white's K-side is destroyed. Oh, and the QR is seriously in danger. In view of all this, 13. Nc3 was necessary, albeit inadequate.
moves.13. Be4: The rest is too painful to watch.
